prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3: SiO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the following molecules. The required sensitivity is 0.20 mJy per 0.5" beam.
SiO(2-1) : LSB (1875 MHz) HNCO : LSB ( 468.75 MHz) CH3OH : USB ( 468.75 MHz) CS(2-1) : USB (1875 MHz)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Required Sensitivity: In band 3, we will observe SiO(2-1), CH3OH(JK=2K-1K), CS(2-1), and continuum emission. We just use SiO for technical justification because of the emission of SiO(2-1) is weakest among 3 molecular lines in the circum-nuclear disk (CND) of NGC1068 (e.g., Aladro et al. 2013). The expected flux of SiO(2-1) is 1.5 mJy in our proposed 0.5" beam (see the detail estimation in the 4th section of our Science Justification). The source size is roughly 300 pc (corresponding <5"), thus can be entirely covered by the maximum angular size scale of band 3. The line width is 250 km/s (FWHM) indicated by Usero et al. 2004, and we request the velocity resolution of 40 km/s. We request the sensitivity of 0.30 mJy per 0.5" beam, which yields 5 sigma detection of SiO(2-1) emission.at the peak of line profile. We will use the SiO(2-1) data not for measurement of line shape but for deriving integrated intensity information which is essential to make rotation (Boltzmann) diagram of SiO. Although the line of H13CO+ is located next to the SiO(2-1), we can de-blend SiO and H13CO+ successfully with the requested velocity resolution (e.g., Usero et al. 2004) We can expect ~2 times higher S/N ratio about CH3OH(JK=2K-1K) and ~7 times higher that of CS(2-1).
The expected peak flux of continuum is 15 mJy per 0.5" beam, which is estimated by the ALMA archive data of band 7 (Garcia-Burillo 2011.0.00083.S). Since the continuum spectrum is flat within band 3, 4, 6, and 7 (Krips et al. 2011), we can simply consider the continuum peak of band 3 as that of band 7. Our requested sensitivity yield more than 900 sigma detection of continuum.
Imaging Requirements: We request 0.5" beam size (corresponding 40 pc at the distance of NGC1068) for band 3, 4, and 6. Having a similar uv-coverage in all observing bands is also important for taking line ratios. Although there is a circum-nuclear starburst ring with a radius of 15" surrounding CND, our attention is CND itself (<5" is expected), thus missing flux is not a serious issue.
Correlator Setup: We will use 3 baseband, each of which consists of one spectral window of 468.750 or 1875 MHz bandwidth. They cover entire line profile of SiO, CH3OH, CS, and wideband continuum. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 40 km/s considering the large velocity width (FWHM ~250 km/s) of these lines.
Calibration: Default calibration is enough.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default calibration is enough.
Scheduling / Time Constraints: none.
Data Rate: Since we request 3 basebands, the expected data rate will be more than 12 MB/s. SiO line is our main target and CS line is indispensable which is used as a reference molecule of SiO relative abundance. CH3OH is also important as a mild shock tracer while SiO traces fast shocks. We will compare the spatial distribution of CH3OH and SiO, which will reveal more detailed shock property in the CND. Therefore we request all 3 basebands though the data rate is large.
Special Constraints on Standard Obserbing Modes: We do not request such constraints.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 4: SiO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the following molecules. The required sensitivity is 0.47 mJy per 0.5" beam.
SiO(3-2) : LSB (937.5 MHz)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Required Sensitivity: In band 4, we will observe SiO(3-2) and continuum emission. The expected peak flux of SiO(2-1) is 1.5 mJy in our proposed 0.5" beam (see the detail estimation in the 4th section of our Science Justification). The source size is roughly 300 pc (corresponding <5"), thus can be entirely covered by the maximum angular size scale of band 3. The line width is 250 km/s (FWHM) indicated by Usero et al. 2004, and we request a velocity resolution of 30 km/s. We request a sensitivity of 0.44 mJy per 0.5" beam, which yields 8 sigma detection of SiO(3-2) emission at the peak of line profile.. This S/N ratio (8 sigma) is indeed necessary to measure the line shape accurately, i.e., to know whether a wing component exists or not.
The expected peak flux of continuum is 15 mJy per 0.5" beam, which is estimated by the ALMA archive data of band 7 (Garcia-Burillo 2011.0.00083.S). Since the continuum spectrum is flat within band 3, 4, 6, and 7 (Krips et al. 2011), we can simply consider the continuum peak of band 4 as that of band 7. Our requested sensitivity yields more than 400 sigma detection of continuum.
Imaging Requirements: We request 0.5" beam size (corresponding 40 pc at the distance of NGC1068) for band 3, 4, and 6. Having a similar uv-coverage in all observing bands is also important for taking line ratios. Although there is a circum-nuclear starburst ring with a radius of 15" surrounding CND, our attention is CND itself (<5" is expected) and thus missing flux is not a serious issue.
Correlator Setup: We will use one baseband, which consists of one spectral window of 1875 MHz bandwidth. They cover entire line profile of SiO and wideband continuum. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 30 km/s considering the large velocity width of the line.
Calibration: Default calibration is enough.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default calibration is enough.
Scheduling / Time Constraints: none.
Data Rate: Since we request just one baseband, we do not expect that the data rate would be more than 12MB/s.
Special Constraints on Standard Obserbing Modes: We do not request such constraints.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6: SiO(5-4)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the following molecules. The required sensitivity is 0.47 mJy per 0.5" beam.
SiO(5-4) : LSB (1875 MHz) 13CO(2-1) : LSB ( 937.5 MHz) C18O(2-1) : LSB (1875 MHz)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Required Sensitivity: In band 6, we will observe SiO(5-4), 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1), and continuum emission Since SiO is our main target molecule, we just use SiO for technical justification. SiO flux is expected to be the weakest among 3 molecular lines since SiO is the weaker than 13CO and C18O in band 3 circum-nuclear disk (CND) of NGC1068 (e.g., Aladro et al. 2013). The expected flux of SiO(5-4) is 3.8 mJy in our proposed 0.5" beam (see the detail estimation in the 4th section of our Science Justification). The source size is roughly 300 pc (corresponding <5"), thus can be entirely covered by the maximum angular size scale of band 6. The line width is 250 km/s (FWHM) indicated by Usero et al. 2004, and we request a velocity resolution of 30 km/s. We request a sensitivity of 0.48 mJy per 0.5" beam, which yields 8 sigma detection of SiO(2-1) emission at the peak of line profile. This S/N ratio (8 sigma) is indeed necessary to measure the line shape accurately, i.e., to know whether a wing component exists or not.
The expected peak flux of continuum is 15 mJy per 0.5" beam, which is estimated by the ALMA archive data of band 7 (Garcia-Burillo 2011.0.00083.S). Since the continuum spectrum is flat within band 3, 4, 6, and 7 (Krips et al. 2011), we can simply consider the continuum peak of band 6 as that of band 7. Our requested sensitivity yields more than 300 sigma detection of continuum.
Imaging Requirements: We request 0.5" beam size (corresponding 40 pc at the distance of NGC1068) for band 3, 4, and 6. Having a similar uv-coverage in all observing bands is also important for taking line ratios. Although there is a circum-nuclear starburst ring with a radius of 15" surrounding CND, our attention is CND itself (<5" is expected), thus missing flux is not a serious issue.
Correlator Setup: We will use 3 baseband, each of which consists of one spectral window of 937.500 MHz bandwidth. They cover entire line profile of SiO, 13CO, C18O, and wideband continuum. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 30 km/s considering the large velocity width (FWHM ~500 km/s) of these lines.
Calibration: Default calibration is enough.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default calibration is enough.
Scheduling / Time Constraints: none.
Data Rate: Since we request 3 basebands, the expected data rate will be more than 12 MB/s. SiO line is our main target and other 2 lines are also indispensable which is used as a reference molecule of SiO relative abundance. Therefore we request all 3 basebands though the data rate is large.
Special Constraints on Standard Obserbing Modes: We do not request such constraints.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6: SiO(6-5)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this science goal, we will observe the following molecules. The required sensitivity is 0.47 mJy per 0.5" beam.
SiO(6-5) : LSB (937.5 MHz) CS(5-4) : USB (937.5 MHz)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Required Sensitivity: In band 6, we will observe SiO(6-5), CS(5-4), and continuum emission. Since SiO is our main target molecule, we just use SiO for technical justification. SiO flux is expected to be the weaker than CS since SiO is the weaker than CS in band 3 circum-nuclear disk (CND) of NGC1068 (e.g., Aladro et al. 2013). The expected flux of SiO(6-5) is 3.0 mJy in our proposed 0.5" beam (see the detail estimation in the 4th section of our Science Justification). The source size is roughly 300 pc (corresponding <5"), thus can be entirely covered by the maximum angular size scale of band 6. The line width is 250 km/s (FWHM) indicated by Usero et al. 2004, and we request a velocity resolution of 30 km/s. We request a sensitivity of 0.38 mJy per 0.5" beam, which yields 8 sigma detection of SiO(6-5) emission at the peak of line profile. This S/N ratio (8 sigma) is indeed necessary to measure the line shape accurately, i.e., to know whether a wing component exists or not.
The expected peak flux of continuum is 15 mJy per 0.5" beam, which is estimated by the ALMA archive data of band 7 (Garcia-Burillo 2011.0.00083.S). Since the continuum spectrum is flat within band 3, 4, 6, and 7 (Krips et al. 2011), we can simply consider the continuum peak of band 6 as that of band 7. Our requested sensitivity yields more than 300 sigma detection of continuum.
Imaging Requirements: We request 0.5" beam size (corresponding 40 pc at the distance of NGC1068) for band 3, 4, and 6. Having a similar uv-coverage in all observing bands is also important for taking line ratios. Although there is a circum-nuclear starburst ring with a radius of 15" surrounding CND, our attention is CND itself (<5" is expected), thus missing flux is not a serious issue.
Correlator Setup: We will use 2 basebands, each of which consists of one spectral window of 1875 MHz bandwidth. They cover entire line profile of SiO, CS, and wideband continuum. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 30 km/s considering the large velocity width (FWHM ~250 km/s) of these lines.
Calibration: Default calibration is enough.
Bandpass Accuracy: Default calibration is enough.
Scheduling / Time Constraints: none.
Data Rate: Since we request only two basebands, we do not expect that the data rate would be more than 12MB/s.
Special Constraints on Standard Obserbing Modes: We do not request such constraints.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The central 300pc circum-nuclear disk (CND) of Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC1068 seems to contain X-ray dominated regions (XDRs) and compact shocked regions. However the contribution of these mechanisms onto the existing molecular gas properties has not yet been clarified.
In this program, we propose to observe the CND of NGC1068 by multiple SiO lines including J=2-1, 3-2, 5-4, and 6-5, which can trace both shocks and XDRs. We will derive the spatial distribution of SiO abundance (via rotation diagram) and kinetic temperature (via LVG analysis) from multi-transition lines. We aim to achieve the following science goals:
(1) constraint of the spatial distribution of XDR: We will compare the obtained SiO abundance map with the existing X-ray flux image. The region where they correlate well is considered to be affected by the XDR.
(2) detailed properties of the bulk of shocked molecular gas at the vicinity of the nucleus: Multiple SiO emissions can trace the bulk of the shocked gas. We will study the spatially resolved physical and chemical properties of shocked gas via temperature, abundance and line shapes.
